problems.title: Any Set is Compact in Co-finite Topology
problems.problem: Suppose $X$ is an infinite set equipped with the cofinite topology. Prove that $X$ is compact.
problems.hint: • The complement of any non-empty open set has only finitely many elements. Now use the definition of compactness to show that the space is compact.
problems.solution: Let $\mathcal{C} \coloneqq \{ U_\alpha \}_{\alpha \in I} $ be an open cover of $X$. Since for each $\alpha \in I$ the set $U_\alpha $ is open and hence $U_{\alpha } = \varnothing $ or $X \setminus U_\alpha $ is a finite set. Let $x_0 \in X$ and let $x_0 \in U_{\alpha _0}$ for some $\alpha _0 \in I$. This implies $X \setminus U_{\alpha _0}$ is finite, that is, \[ X \setminus U_{\alpha _0} = \{x_1, x_2, \dots, x_k\}. \] Choose $\alpha _i \in I$ such that $x_i \in U_{\alpha _i}$. Thus, we have a finite subcover of $\mathcal{C} $, namely, $\{ U_{\alpha _0}, U_{\alpha _1}, \dots, U_{\alpha _k} \} $. Therefore, $X$ is compact.

problems.title: Some Problem
problems.problem:
On the real line $\mathbb{R} $, consider the collection of subsets 
    \[
        \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow } \coloneqq \{ \varnothing , \mathbb{R}  \}  \cup \{ (-\infty ,a): a \in \mathbb{R}  \}  .
    \] 
    Show that $\mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$ is a topology on $\mathbb{R} $.
problems.hint:
• If $\{ U_\alpha = (-\infty ,\alpha ) : \alpha \in I \}\subset \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$, then consider the supremum of all such $\alpha $.
  • If $F_i = (-\infty , \alpha _i) \in \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$, $i =1,2,\dots,n $, then consider the minimum of such $\alpha _i$.
problems.solution:
Recall that $\mathcal{T} $ is a topology on a set $X$, if the following holds:
  1. $X, \varnothing \in \mathcal{T} $;
  2. If $U_\alpha \in \mathcal{T} $ for $\alpha \in I$, then $ \cup U_\alpha \in \mathcal{T} $;
  3. If $F_i \in \mathcal{T} $ for $i = 1,2,\dots,n$, then $ \cap F_i \in \mathcal{T} $.
We will verify each of these conditions.
  1. True as it is given that $\varnothing , \mathbb{R} \in \mathcal{T}_{\leftarrow }.$
  2. Let $\{ U_\alpha = (-\infty ,\alpha ) : \alpha \in I \}\subset \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$, where $I$ is an index set. We need to show that $ \cup (-\infty ,\alpha ) \in \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$. Consider the collection $\mathcal{A} = \{\alpha \in \mathbb{R} : \alpha \in I\}$, and let $\alpha _0 = \sup \mathcal{A} $. It is clear that $\alpha _0 \in \mathbb{R} $ and also $ \cup U_\alpha = (-\infty ,\alpha _0)\in \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$.
  3. Let $F_i = (-\infty , \alpha _i) \in \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$, $i =1,2,\dots,n $. Since the collection $\{ \alpha _i \in \mathbb{R} : i = 1,2,\dots, n \} $ is finite, let $\alpha _0$ is the minimum of the collection and $ \cap (-\infty ,\alpha _i) = (-\infty ,\alpha _0) \in \mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$.
Thus, $\mathcal{T} _{\leftarrow }$ is a topology on $\mathbb{R} $.

problems.title: Fixed point set of a continuous function is closed
problems.problem:
Let $\mathbb{R} $ be equipped with the usual Euclidean topology. If $f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} $ is a continuous function, show that the set of points which are left fixed by $f$ is a closed subset of $\mathbb{R} $.
Also generalize the same for a Hausdorff topological space $X$ and a continuous function $f: X \to X$.
problems.hint:
• Consider $g(x) = f(x) - x$.
  • Use the condition that the topology is Hausdorff. Show that the complement is open.
problems.solution:
Let \[ \mathcal{F} = \{ x\in \mathbb{R} : f(x) = x \} . \] We need to show that $\mathcal{F} $ is closed subset of $\mathbb{R} .$ Consider a function $g: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} $ \[ g(x) = f(x) - x. \] It is clear that $g$ is continuous and $\mathcal{F} = g^{-1} (\{ 0 \} )$. Since $\{ 0 \} $ is a closed set and $g$ is continuous, $\mathcal{F} = g^{-1} \{ 0 \} $ is closed in $\mathbb{R} $.
This problem can be solved for an arbitrary Hausdorff topological space $X$ and a continuous function on $X$. More precisely, if $X$ is a topological space which is Hausdorff and $f: X \to X$ is continuous, then the fixed point set of $f$ is closed in $X$ . We will show that $\mathcal{F} ^c = \mathbb{R} \setminus \mathcal{F} $ is open in $\mathbb{R} $. Let $a \in \mathcal{F} ^c$, which implies $f(a) \neq a$. As the standard topology on $\mathbb{R} $ is Hausdorff, we can find neighborhoods $U \text{ and } V$ of $f(a) \text{ and } a$, respectively, such that $U \cap V = \varnothing .$ Since $f$ is continuous, $f^{-1} (V)$ is an open neighborhood of $a$ and hence $U \cap f^{-1} (V)$ is an open neighborhood of $a$. We now claim that $\mathcal{O} \coloneqq U \cap f^{-1} (V) \subseteq \mathcal{F} ^c$.
To the contrary, if $x \in \mathcal{O} \cap \mathcal{F} $, then $x \in U, x \in f^{-1} (V)$ and $x \in \mathcal{F} $ which implies $f(x) = x$. Since \[ x \in f^{-1} (V) \implies f(x) \in V \implies x = f(x) \in V \implies x \in U \cap V, \] a contradiction.
